result.description: The root node of the server-level management model.

management-major-version.description: The major version of the JBoss AS management interface that is provided by this server.

running-mode.description: The current running mode of the server. Either NORMAL (normal operations) or ADMIN_ONLY.  An ADMIN_ONLY server will start any configured management interfaces and accept management requests, but will not start services used for handling end user requests.

product-name.description: The name of the JBoss AS based product that is being run by this server.

server-state.description: The current state of the server controller; either STARTING, RUNNING or RESTART_REQUIRED

release-version.description: The version of the JBoss Application Server release this server is running.

namespaces.description: Map of namespaces used in the configuration XML document, where keys are namespace prefixes and values are schema URIs.

management-micro-version.description: The micro version of the JBoss AS management interface that is provided by this server.

process-type.description: The type of process represented by this root resource. Always has a value of "Server" for a server resource.

launch-type.description: The manner in which the server process was launched. Either "DOMAIN" for a domain mode server launched by a Host Controller, "STANDALONE" for a standalone server launched from the command line, or "EMBEDDED" for a standalone server launched as an embedded part of an application running in the same virtual machine.

name.description: The name of this server. If not set, defaults to the runtime value of InetAddress.getLocalHost().getHostName().

profile-name.description: The name of the server's configuration profile.

release-codename.description: The codename of the JBoss Application Server release this server is running.

schema-locations.description: Map of locations of XML schemas used in the configuration XML document, where keys are schema URIs and values are locations where the schema can be found.

product-version.description: The version of the JBoss AS based product release that is being run by this server.

management-minor-version.description: The minor version of the JBoss AS management interface that is provided by this server.

core-service.description: Core services provided by the server.

service-container.description: The central container that manages all services in a running standalone server or in a host controller in a management domain.

module.description: The name of the module to load up the vault implementation from.

code.description: Fully Qualified Name of the Security Vault Implementation.

config-file.description: The configuration file used to launch JBoss Application Server.

initial-running-mode.description: The current running mode of the server. Either LIVE (normal operations) or ADMIN_ONLY.  An ADMIN_ONLY server will start any configured management interfaces and accept management requests, but will not start services used for handling end user requests.

content-dir.description: The directory where user content (e.g. deployments) that is managed by the server is stored.

log-dir.description: The directory where log files are sent.

node-name.description: The name of the server node.

base-dir.description: The base directory for JBoss Application Server.

home-dir.description: The home directory for JBoss Application Server.

launch-type.description: The type of the running server.

modules-dir.description: The directory where modules are found.

config-dir.description: The directory where the configurations are stored.

module-roots.description: A list of filesystem locations under which the module loading system looks for modules, arranged in order of precedence.

deprecated.reason: Experimental and unsupported.

module-root.description: Filesystem location under which the module loading system looks for modules.

platform-mbean.description: Provides the management interface for monitoring and management of the Java virtual machine as well as the operating system on which the Java virtual machine is running. Exposes the JDK-provided JMX MBeans in the java.lang, java.nio and java.util.logging JMX domains.

type.description: The platform MBeans, organized by the value of the 'type' property in the MBean's ObjectName.

compilation.description: The management interface for the compilation system of the Java virtual machine

object-name.description: String representation the object name of this platform managed object.

compilation-time-monitoring-supported.description: Whether the Java virtual machine supports the monitoring of compilation time.

total-compilation-time.description: The approximate accumulated elapsed time (in milliseconds) spent in compilation. A Java virtual machine implementation may not support compilation time monitoring. If "compilation-time-monitoring-supported", is "false" trying to read this attribute via the "read-attribute" operation will result in failure, and the value of this attribute in the result of a "read-resource" operation will be "undefined".

name.description: The name of the Just-in-time (JIT) compiler.

memory-manager.description: The management interface for a memory manager. A memory manager manages one or more memory pools of the Java virtual machine.

name.description: The name representing this memory manager.

*.description: The management interface for a memory manager. A memory manager manages one or more memory pools of the Java virtual machine.

object-name.description: String representation the object name of this platform managed object.

valid.description: Whether this memory manager is valid in the Java virtual machine.

memory-pool-names.description: The names of the memory pools that this memory manager manages.

name.description: The name representing this memory manager.

garbage-collector.description: Parent resource for the resources providing the management interface for the garbage collection of the Java virtual machine.

name.description: The GarbageCollectorMXBean platform MBeans, organized by the value of the 'name' property in the MBean's ObjectName.

*.description: The management interface for one of the garbage collectors in the Java virtual machine.

collection-time.description: The approximate accumulated collection elapsed time in milliseconds.

valid.description: Whether this this memory manager is valid in the Java virtual machine.

object-name.description: String representation the object name of this platform managed object.

collection-count.description: The total number of collections that have occurred.

name.description: The name representing this garbage collector.

memory-pool-names.description: The name of memory pools that this garbage collector manages.

memory.description: The management interface for the memory system of the Java virtual machine.

non-heap-memory-usage.description: The current memory usage of non-heap memory that is used by the Java virtual machine.

init.description: The amount of memory in bytes that the Java virtual machine initially requests from the operating system for memory management.

used.description: The amount of used memory in bytes.

committed.description: The amount of memory in bytes that is committed for the Java virtual machine to use.

max.description: The maximum amount of memory in bytes that can be used for memory management.

heap-memory-usage.description: The current memory usage of the heap that is used for object allocation.

init.description: The amount of memory in bytes that the Java virtual machine initially requests from the operating system for memory management.

used.description: The amount of used memory in bytes.

committed.description: The amount of memory in bytes that is committed for the Java virtual machine to use.

max.description: The maximum amount of memory in bytes that can be used for memory management.

verbose.description: Whether verbose output for the memory system is enabled.

object-name.description: String representation the object name of this platform managed object.

object-pending-finalization-count.description: The approximate number of objects for which finalization is pending.

threading.description: The management interface for the thread system of the Java virtual machine.

total-started-thread-count.description: The total number of threads created and also started since the Java virtual machine started.

object-name.description: String representation the object name of this platform managed object.

thread-cpu-time-supported.description: Whether the Java virtual machine implementation supports CPU time measurement for any thread.

current-thread-cpu-time-supported.description: Whether the Java virtual machine supports CPU time measurement for the current thread.

synchronizer-usage-supported.description: Whether the Java virtual machine supports monitoring of ownable synchronizer usage.

all-thread-ids.description: All live thread IDs. If a security manager is installed and the caller does not have ManagementPermission("monitor"), then a "read-attribute" operation reading this attribute will fail, and the value for this attribute in the result for the "read-resource" operation will be "undefined".

peak-thread-count.description: The peak live thread count since the Java virtual machine started or peak was reset.

daemon-thread-count.description: The current number of live daemon threads.

thread-count.description: The current number of live threads including both daemon and non-daemon threads.

current-thread-cpu-time.description: The total CPU time for the current thread in nanoseconds, or -1 if "thread-cpu-time-enabled" is "false". A Java virtual machine implementation may not support CPU time measurement. If "thread-cpu-time-supported", is "false" trying to read this attribute via the "read-attribute" operation will result in failure, and the value of this attribute in the result of a "read-resource" operation will be "undefined".

current-thread-user-time.description: The CPU time that the current thread has executed in user mode in nanoseconds, or -1 if "thread-cpu-time-enabled" is "false". A Java virtual machine implementation may not support CPU time measurement. If "thread-cpu-time-supported", is "false" trying to read this attribute via the "read-attribute" operation will result in failure, and the value of this attribute in the result of a "read-resource" operation will be "undefined".

thread-cpu-time-enabled.description: Whether thread CPU time measurement is enabled.

thread-contention-monitoring-enabled.description: Whether thread contention monitoring is enabled.

thread-contention-monitoring-supported.description: Whether the Java virtual machine supports thread contention monitoring.

object-monitor-usage-supported.description: Whether the Java virtual machine supports monitoring of object monitor usage.

operating-system.description: The management interface for the operating system on which the Java virtual machine is running.

system-load-average.description: The system load average for the last minute. The load average may not be available on some platforms; if the load average is not available, a negative value is returned.

arch.description: The operating system architecture. If a security manager is installed and it does not allow access to system property "os.arch", then a "read-attribute" operation reading this attribute will fail, and the value for this attribute in the result for the "read-resource" operation will be "undefined".

object-name.description: String representation the object name of this platform managed object.

name.description: The operating system name. If a security manager is installed and it does not allow access to system property "os.name", then a "read-attribute" operation reading this attribute will fail, and the value for this attribute in the result for the "read-resource" operation will be "undefined".

available-processors.description: The number of processors available to the Java virtual machine.

version.description: The operating system version. If a security manager is installed and it does not allow access to system property "os.version", then a "read-attribute" operation reading this attribute will fail, and the value for this attribute in the result for the "read-resource" operation will be "undefined".

buffer-pool.description: The management interface for a buffer pool, for example a pool of direct or mapped buffers.

name.description: The name representing this buffer pool.
The name representing this buffer pool.

*.description: The management interface for a buffer pool, for example a pool of direct or mapped buffers.

memory-used.description: An estimate of the memory that the Java virtual machine is using for this buffer pool in bytes, or -1 if an estimate of the memory usage is not available.

count.description: An estimate of the number of buffers in the pool.

object-name.description: String representation the object name of this platform managed object.

name.description: The name representing this buffer pool.

total-capacity.description: An estimate of the total capacity of the buffers in this pool. A buffer's capacity is the number of elements it contains and the value of this attribute is an estimate of the total capacity of buffers in the pool in bytes.

memory-pool.description: The management interface for a memory pool. A memory pool represents the memory resource managed by the Java virtual machine and is managed by one or more memory managers.

name.description: The name representing this memory pool.

*.description: The management interface for a memory pool. A memory pool represents the memory resource managed by the Java virtual machine and is managed by one or more memory managers.

usage-threshold.description: The usage threshold value of this memory pool in bytes. A memory pool may not support a usage threshold. If "usage-threshold-supported", is "false" trying to read this attribute via the "read-attribute" operation will result in failure, and the value of this attribute in the result of a "read-resource" operation will be "undefined".

valid.description: Whether this memory pool is valid in the Java virtual machine. A memory pool becomes invalid once the Java virtual machine removes it from the memory system.

collection-usage-threshold-count.description: The number of times that the Java virtual machine has detected that the memory usage has reached or exceeded the collection usage threshold. A memory pool may not support a collection usage threshold. If "collection-usage-threshold-supported", is "false" trying to read this attribute via the "read-attribute" operation will result in failure, and the value of this attribute in the result of a "read-resource" operation will be "undefined".

collection-usage-threshold.description: The collection usage threshold value of this memory pool in bytes. A memory pool may not support a collection usage threshold. If "collection-usage-threshold-supported", is "false" trying to read this attribute via the "read-attribute" operation will result in failure, and the value of this attribute in the result of a "read-resource" operation will be "undefined".

object-name.description: String representation the object name of this platform managed object.

type.description: The type of this memory pool.

collection-usage-threshold-exceeded.description: Whether the memory usage of this memory pool after the most recent collection on which the Java virtual machine has expended effort has reached or exceeded its collection usage threshold. A memory pool may not support a collection usage threshold. If "collection-usage-threshold-supported", is "false" trying to read this attribute via the "read-attribute" operation will result in failure, and the value of this attribute in the result of a "read-resource" operation will be "undefined".

collection-usage-threshold-supported.description: Whether this memory pool supports a collection usage threshold.

usage-threshold-count.description: The number of times that the memory usage has crossed the usage threshold. A memory pool may not support a usage threshold. If "usage-threshold-supported", is "false" trying to read this attribute via the "read-attribute" operation will result in failure, and the value of this attribute in the result of a "read-resource" operation will be "undefined".

peak-usage.description: The peak memory usage of this memory pool since the Java virtual machine was started or since the peak was reset. May be "undefined" if attribute "valid" is "false".

init.description: The amount of memory in bytes that the Java virtual machine initially requests from the operating system for memory management.

used.description: The amount of used memory in bytes.

committed.description: The amount of memory in bytes that is committed for the Java virtual machine to use.

max.description: The maximum amount of memory in bytes that can be used for memory management.

name.description: The name representing this memory pool.

memory-manager-names.description: The names of the memory managers that manage this memory pool.

usage.description: An estimate of the memory usage of this memory pool. May be "undefined" if attribute "valid" is "false".

init.description: The amount of memory in bytes that the Java virtual machine initially requests from the operating system for memory management.

used.description: The amount of used memory in bytes.

committed.description: The amount of memory in bytes that is committed for the Java virtual machine to use.

max.description: The maximum amount of memory in bytes that can be used for memory management.

usage-threshold-exceeded.description: Whether the memory usage of this memory pool reaches or exceeds its usage threshold value.  A memory pool may not support a usage threshold. If "usage-threshold-supported", is "false" trying to read this attribute via the "read-attribute" operation will result in failure, and the value of this attribute in the result of a "read-resource" operation will be "undefined".

usage-threshold-supported.description: Whether this memory pool supports usage threshold.

collection-usage.description: The memory usage after the Java virtual machine most recently expended effort in recycling unused objects in this memory pool, or "undefined" if this attribute is not supported.

init.description: The amount of memory in bytes that the Java virtual machine initially requests from the operating system for memory management.

used.description: The amount of used memory in bytes.

committed.description: The amount of memory in bytes that is committed for the Java virtual machine to use.

max.description: The maximum amount of memory in bytes that can be used for memory management.

runtime.description: The management interface for the runtime system of the Java virtual machine.

input-arguments.description: The input arguments passed to the Java virtual machine which does not include the arguments to the main method. If a security manager is installed and the caller does not have ManagementPermission("monitor"), then a "read-attribute" operation reading this attribute will fail, and the value for this attribute in the result for the "read-resource" operation will be "undefined".

class-path.description: The Java class path that is used by the system class loader to search for class files. If a security manager is installed and it does not allow access to system property "java.class.path", then a "read-attribute" operation reading this attribute will fail, and the value for this attribute in the result for the "read-resource" operation will be "undefined".

object-name.description: String representation the object name of this platform managed object.

vm-name.description: The Java virtual machine implementation name. If a security manager is installed and it does not allow access to system property "java.vm.name", then a "read-attribute" operation reading this attribute will fail, and the value for this attribute in the result for the "read-resource" operation will be "undefined".

vm-version.description: The Java virtual machine implementation version. If a security manager is installed and it does not allow access to system property "java.vm.version", then a "read-attribute" operation reading this attribute will fail, and the value for this attribute in the result for the "read-resource" operation will be "undefined".

spec-vendor.description: The Java virtual machine specification vendor. If a security manager is installed and it does not allow access to system property "java.vm.specification.vendor", then a "read-attribute" operation reading this attribute will fail, and the value for this attribute in the result for the "read-resource" operation will be "undefined".

boot-class-path-supported.description: Whether the Java virtual machine supports the boot class path mechanism used by the bootstrap class loader to search for class files.

start-time.description: The start time of the Java virtual machine in milliseconds.

uptime.description: The uptime of the Java virtual machine in milliseconds.

library-path.description: The Java library path. If a security manager is installed and it does not allow access to system property "java.library.path", then a "read-attribute" operation reading this attribute will fail, and the value for this attribute in the result for the "read-resource" operation will be "undefined".

spec-version.description: The Java virtual machine specification version. If a security manager is installed and it does not allow access to system property "java.vm.specification.version", then a "read-attribute" operation reading this attribute will fail, and the value for this attribute in the result for the "read-resource" operation will be "undefined".

spec-name.description: The Java virtual machine specification name. If a security manager is installed and it does not allow access to system property "java.vm.specification.name", then a "read-attribute" operation reading this attribute will fail, and the value for this attribute in the result for the "read-resource" operation will be "undefined".

management-spec-version.description: The version of the specification for the management interface implemented by the running Java virtual machine.

system-properties.description: A map of names and values of all system properties. If a security manager is installed and its "checkPropertiesAccess" method does not allow access to system properties, then a "read-attribute" operation reading this attribute will fail, and the value for this attribute in the result for the "read-resource" operation will be "undefined".

boot-class-path.description: The boot class path that is used by the bootstrap class loader to search for class files. If attribute "boot-class-path-supported" is "false" or if a security manager is installed and the caller does not have ManagementPermission("monitor"), then a "read-attribute" operation reading this attribute will fail, and the value for this attribute in the result for the "read-resource" operation will be "undefined".

name.description: The name representing the running Java virtual machine.

vm-vendor.description: The Java virtual machine implementation vendor. If a security manager is installed and it does not allow access to system property "java.vm.vendor", then a "read-attribute" operation reading this attribute will fail, and the value for this attribute in the result for the "read-resource" operation will be "undefined".

class-loading.description: The management interface for the class loading system of the Java virtual machine.

total-loaded-class-count.description: The total number of classes that have been loaded since the Java virtual machine has started execution.

loaded-class-count.description: The number of classes that are currently loaded in the Java virtual machine.

verbose.description: Whether the verbose output for the class loading system is enabled.

unloaded-class-count.description: The total number of classes unloaded since the Java virtual machine has started execution.

object-name.description: String representation the object name of this platform managed object.

management.description: The management services used to control a server or a host's host controller.

access.description: Model representation for configuration affecting access control and auditing of access.

audit.description: The management audit logging top-level resource.

audit-log.description: The management audit logging top-level resource.

enabled.description: Whether audit logging is enabled.

log-boot.description: Whether operations should be logged on server boot.

log-read-only.description: Whether operations that do not modify the configuration or any runtime services should be logged.

handler.description: References to file or syslog audit log appenders.

*.description: A reference to a file or syslog audit log handler. The name of the handler is denoted by the value of the address.

json-formatter.description: Formatters for formatting the audit log messages using json.

*.description: A json formatter for audit log messages.

date-separator.description: The separator between the date and the rest of the formatted log message. Will be ignored if include-date="false".

compact.description: If true will format the JSON on one line. There may still be values containing new lines, so if having the whole record on one line is important, set escape-new-line or escape-control-characters to true.

escape-control-characters.description:
If true will escape all control characters (ascii entries with a decimal value < 32) with the ascii code in octal, e.g.'
 becomes '#012'. If this is true, it will override escape-new-line="false".

date-format.description: The date format to use as understood by {@link java.text.SimpleDateFormat}. Will be ignored if include-date="false".

escape-new-line.description: If true will escape all new lines with the ascii code in octal, e.g. "#012".

include-date.description: Whether or not to include the date in the formatted log record.

file-handler.description: File handlers for use with the management audit logging service.

*.description: A file handler for use with the management audit logging service.

formatter.description: The formatter used to format the log messages.

disabled-due-to-failure.description: Whether this handler has been disabled due to logging failures.

max-failure-count.description: The maximum number of logging failures before disabling this handler.

relative-to.description: The name of another previously named path, or of one of the standard paths provided by the system. If 'relative-to' is provided, the value of the 'path' attribute is treated as relative to the path specified by this attribute.

path.description: The path of the audit log file.

failure-count.description: The number of logging failures since the handler was initialized.

syslog-handler.description: Syslog handlers for use with the management audit logging service.

*.description: A syslog handler for use with the management audit logging service.

formatter.description: The formatter used to format the log messages.

app-name.description: The application name to add to the syslog records as defined in section 6.2.5 of RFC-5424. If not specified it will default to the name of the product.

disabled-due-to-failure.description: Whether this handler has been disabled due to logging failures.

max-length.description: The maximum length in bytes a log message, including the header, is allowed to be. If undefined, it will default to 1024 bytes if the syslog-format is RFC3164, or 2048 bytes if the syslog-format is RFC5424.

facility.description: The facility to use for syslog logging as defined in section 6.2.1 of RFC-5424, and section 4.1.1 of RFC-3164.

truncate.description: Whether or not a message, including the header, should truncate the message if the length in bytes is greater than the maximum length. If set to false messages will be split and sent with the same header values.

max-failure-count.description: The maximum number of logging failures before disabling this handler.

failure-count.description: The number of logging failures since the handler was initialized.

syslog-format.description: Whether to set the syslog format to the one specified in RFC-5424 or RFC-3164.

protocol.description: The protocol to use for the syslog handler. Must be one and only one of 'udp', 'tcp' or 'tls'.

tcp.description: Configuration to append to syslog over tcp/ip.

port.description: The port of the syslog server for the tcp requests.

message-transfer.description: The message transfer setting as described in section 3.4 of RFC-6587. This can either be OCTET_COUNTING as described in section 3.4.1 of RFC-6587, or NON_TRANSPARENT_FRAMING as described in section 3.4.1 of RFC-6587. See your syslog provider's documentation for what is supported.

host.description: The host of the syslog server for the tcp requests.

tls.description: Configuration to append to syslog over tls over tcp/ip.

port.description: The port of the syslog server for the tls over tcp requests.

message-transfer.description: The message transfer setting as described in section 3.4 of RFC-6587. This can either be OCTET_COUNTING as described in section 3.4.1 of RFC-6587, or NON_TRANSPARENT_FRAMING as described in section 3.4.1 of RFC-6587. See your syslog provider's documentation for what is supported.

host.description: The host of the syslog server for the tls over tcp requests.

authentication.description: Configuration for the truststore for the server certificate if not signed by an authority, and the keystore containing the client certificate if the syslog server is set up to require client authentication.

client-certificate-store.description: Configuration for the keystore containing the client certificate if the syslog server requires authentication.

keystore-relative-to.description: The name of another previously named path, or of one of the standard paths provided by the system. If 'keystore-relative-to' is provided, the value of the 'keystore-path' attribute is treated as relative to the path specified by this attribute.

key-password.description: The password for the keystore key.

truststore.description: Configuration for the truststore for the server certificate, if not signed by an authority.

keystore-relative-to.description: The name of another previously named path, or of one of the standard paths provided by the system. If 'keystore-relative-to' is provided, the value of the 'keystore-path' attribute is treated as relative to the path specified by this attribute.

udp.description: Configuration to append to syslog over udp/ip.

port.description: The port of the syslog server for the udp requests.

host.description: The host of the syslog server for the udp requests.

authorization.description: The access control definitions defining the access management restrictions.

all-role-names.description: The official names of all roles supported by the current management access control provider. This includes any standard roles as well as any user-defined roles.

provider.description: The provider to use for management access control decisions.

permission-combination-policy.description: The policy for combining access control permissions when the authorization policy grants the user more than one type of permission for a given action. In the standard role based authorization policy, this would occur when a user maps to multiple roles. The 'permissive' policy means if any of the permissions allow the action, the action is allowed. The 'rejecting' policy means the existence of multiple permissions should result in an error.

standard-role-names.description: The official names of the standard roles supported by the current management access control provider.

*.description: A thread pool executor with a bounded queue where threads submittings tasks will not block. Such a thread pool has a core and maximum size and a specified queue length.  When a task is submitted, if the number of running threads is less than the core size, a new thread is created.  Otherwise, if there is room in the queue, the task is enqueued. Otherwise, if the number of running threads is less than the maximum size, a new thread is created. Otherwise, the task is handed off to the designated handoff executor, if one is specified.  Otherwise, the task is discarded.

Otherwise, the task is discarded.

The template used to create names for threads.  The following patterns may be used:
	%% - emit a percent sign
	%t - emit the per-factory thread sequence number
	%g - emit the global thread sequence number
	%f - emit the factory sequence number
	%i - emit the thread ID.

*.description: A thread pool executor with a bounded queue where threads submittings tasks may block. Such a thread pool has a core and maximum size and a specified queue length.  When a task is submitted, if the number of running threads is less than the core size, a new thread is created.  Otherwise, if there is room in the queue, the task is enqueued. Otherwise, if the number of running threads is less than the maximum size, a new thread is created. Otherwise, the caller blocks until room becomes available in the queue.

core-threads.description: The core thread pool size which is smaller than the maximum pool size. If undefined, the core thread pool size is the same as the maximum thread pool size.

When a task is submitted, if the number of running threads is less than the maximum size, a new thread is created.  Otherwise, the caller blocks until another thread completes its task and accepts the new one.

sar.description: The SAR subsystem allowing you to deploy sar archives containing MBeans configured by META-INF/jboss-service.xml

jgroups.description: The configuration of the JGroups subsystem.

stack.description: The configuration of a JGroups protocol stack.

protocols.description: The list of configured protocols for a protocol stack.

type.description: The implementation class for a protocol, which determines protocol functionality.

socket-binding.description: The socket binding specification for this protocol layer, used to specify IP interfaces and ports for communication.

property.description: A JGroups protocol property.

*.description: A protocol property with name and value.

value.description: The value of a protocol property.

TRANSPORT.description: The configuration of a transport for a protocol stack.

shared.description: If true, the underlying transport is shared by all channels using this stack.

default-executor.description: The thread pool executor to handle incoming messages.

site.description: The site (i.e. data centre) identifier for this node. Used by Infinispan topology-aware consistent hash.

rack.description: The rack (i.e. server rack) identifier for this node. Used by Infinispan topology-aware consistent hash.

type.description: The implementation class for a protocol, which determines protocol functionality.

socket-binding.description: The socket binding specification for this protocol layer, used to specify IP interfaces and ports for communication.

machine.description: The machine (i.e. host) identifier for this node. Used by Infinispan topology-aware consistent hash.

oob-executor.description: The thread pool executor to handle incoming out-of-band messages.

thread-factory.description: The thread factory to use for handling asynchronous transport-specific tasks.

timer-executor.description: The thread pool executor to handle protocol-related timing tasks.

diagnostics-socket-binding.description: The diagnostics socket binding specification for this protocol layer, used to specify IP interfaces and ports for communication.

property.description: A JGroups transport property.

*.description: A protocol property with name and value.

value.description: The value of a protocol property.

remoting.description: The configuration of the Remoting subsystem.

worker-read-threads.description: The number of read threads to create for the remoting worker.

worker-task-max-threads.description: The maximum number of threads for the remoting worker task thread pool.

worker-task-limit.description: The maximum number of remoting worker tasks to allow before rejecting.

worker-task-core-threads.description: The number of core threads for the remoting worker task thread pool.

worker-write-threads.description: The number of write threads to create for the remoting worker.

worker-task-keepalive.description: The number of milliseconds to keep non-core remoting worker task threads alive.

*.description: Remoting outbound connection.

uri.description: The connection URI for the outbound connection.

property.description: The XNIO Options that will be used during the connection creation.

*.description: Properties supported by the underlying provider. The property name is inferred from the last element of the properties address.

value.description: The property value.

remote-outbound-connection.description: Remoting outbound connections for remote:// URI scheme.

*.description: Remoting outbound connection with a implicit remote:// URI scheme.

outbound-socket-binding-ref.description: Name of the outbound-socket-binding which will be used to determine the destination address and port for the connection.

username.description: The user name to use when authenticating against the remote server.

security-realm.description: Reference to the security realm to use to obtain the password and SSL configuration.

property.description: The XNIO Options that will be used during the connection creation.

*.description: Properties supported by the underlying provider. The property name is inferred from the last element of the properties address.

value.description: The property value.

*.description: The configuration of a Remoting connector.

authentication-provider.description: The "authentication-provider" element contains the name of the authentication provider to use for incoming connections.

socket-binding.description: The name (or names) of the socket binding(s) to attach to.

security-realm.description: The associated security realm to use for authentication for this connector.

security.description: Configuration of security for this connector.

sasl.description: The "sasl" element contains the SASL authentication configuration for this connector.

qop.description: The optional nested "qop" element contains a list of quality-of-protection values, in decreasing order of preference.

include-mechanisms.description: The optional nested "include-mechanisms" element contains a whitelist of allowed SASL mechanism names. No mechanisms will be allowed which are not present in this list.

strength.description: The optional nested "strength" element contains a list of cipher strength values, in decreasing order of preference.

server-auth.description: The optional nested "server-auth" boolean element specifies whether the server should authenticate to the client.  Not all mechanisms may support this setting.

reuse-session.description: The optional nested "reuse-session" boolean element specifies whether or not the server should attempt to reuse previously authenticated session information.  The mechanism may or may not support such reuse, and other factors may also prevent it.

sasl-policy.description: Specifies an optional policy to use to narrow down the available set of mechanisms.

forward-secrecy.description: The optional nested "forward-secrecy" element contains a boolean value which specifies whether mechanisms that implement forward secrecy between sessions are required. Forward secrecy means that breaking into one session will not automatically provide information for breaking into future sessions.

no-plain-text.description: The optional nested "no-plain-text" element contains a boolean value which specifies whether mechanisms susceptible to simple plain passive attacks (e.g., "PLAIN") are not permitted.    "false" to permit, "true" to deny.

no-active.description: The optional nested "no-active" element contains a boolean value which specifies whether mechanisms susceptible to active (non-dictionary) attacks are not permitted. "false" to permit, "true" to deny.

pass-credentials.description: The optional nested "pass-credentials" element contains a boolean value which specifies whether mechanisms that pass client credentials are required.

no-dictionary.description: The optional nested "no-dictionary" element contains a boolean value which specifies whether mechanisms susceptible to passive dictionary attacks are permitted.  "false" to permit, "true" to deny.

no-anonymous.description: The optional nested "no-anonymous" element contains a boolean value which specifies whether mechanisms that accept anonymous login are permitted.  "false" to permit, "true" to deny.

infinispan.description: The configuration of the infinispan subsystem.

cache-container.description: The configuration of an infinispan cache container

*.description: The configuration of an infinispan cache container

module.description: The module whose class loader should be used when building this cache's configuration.

cache-manager-status.description: The status of the cache manager component. May return null if the cache manager is not started.

statistics-enabled.description: If enabled, statistics will be collected for this cache

replication-queue-executor.description: The executor used for asynchronous cache operations

local-address.description: The local address of the node. May return null if the cache manager is not started.

coordinator-address.description: The logical address of the cluster's coordinator. May return null if the cache manager is not started.

aliases.description: The list of aliases for this cache container

alias.description: An alias for this cache container

eviction-executor.description: The scheduled executor used for eviction

cluster-name.description: The name of the cluster this node belongs to. May return null if the cache manager is not started.

start.description: The cache start mode, which can be EAGER (immediate start) or LAZY (on-demand start).

jndi-name.description: The jndi-name to which to bind this cache instance.

is-coordinator.description: Set to true if this node is the cluster's coordinator. May return null if the cache manager is not started.

listener-executor.description: The executor used for the replication queue

replicated-cache.description: A replicated cache child of the cache container.

*.description: A replicated cache

cache-status.description: The status of the cache component. May return null if the cache is not started.

hit-ratio.description: The hit/miss ratio for the cache (hits/hits+misses). May return null if the cache is not started.

indexing.description: If enabled, entries will be indexed when they are added to the cache. Indexes will be updated as entries change or are removed.

passivations.description: The number of cache node passivations (passivating a node from memory to a cache store). May return null if the cache is not started.

remove-misses.description: The number of cache attribute remove misses. May return null if the cache is not started.

misses.description: The number of cache attribute misses. May return null if the cache is not started.

mode.description: Sets the clustered cache mode, ASYNC for asynchronous operation, or SYNC for synchronous operation.

remote-timeout.description: In SYNC mode, the timeout (in ms) used to wait for an acknowledgment when making a remote call, after which the call is aborted and an exception is thrown.

number-of-entries.description: The current number of entries in the cache. May return null if the cache is not started.

time-since-reset.description: Time (in secs) since cache statistics were reset. May return null if the cache is not started.

jndi-name.description: The jndi-name to which to bind this cache instance.

elapsed-time.description: Time (in secs) since cache started. May return null if the cache is not started.

read-write-ratio.description: The read/write ratio of the cache ((hits+misses)/stores). May return null if the cache is not started.

remove-hits.description: The number of cache attribute remove hits. May return null if the cache is not started.

queue-size.description: In ASYNC mode, this attribute can be used to trigger flushing of the queue when it reaches a specific threshold.

async-marshalling.description: If enabled, this will cause marshalling of entries to be performed asynchronously.

queue-flush-interval.description: In ASYNC mode, this attribute controls how often the asynchronous thread used to flush the replication queue runs. This should be a positive integer which represents thread wakeup time in milliseconds.

replication-count.description: The number of times data was replicated around the cluster. May return null if the cache is not started.

module.description: The module whose class loader should be used when building this cache's configuration.

average-read-time.description: Average time (in ms) for cache reads. Includes hits and misses. May return null if the cache is not started.

success-ratio.description: The data replication success ratio (successes/successes+failures). May return null if the cache is not started.

invalidations.description: The number of cache invalidations. May return null if the cache is not started.

replication-failures.description: The number of data replication failures. May return null if the cache is not started.

statistics-enabled.description: If enabled, statistics will be collected for this cache

hits.description: The number of cache attribute hits. May return null if the cache is not started.

batching.description: If enabled, the invocation batching API will be made available for this cache.

start.description: The cache start mode, which can be EAGER (immediate start) or LAZY (on-demand start).

average-write-time.description: Average time (in ms) for cache writes. May return null if the cache is not started.

stores.description: The number of cache attribute put operations. May return null if the cache is not started.

average-replication-time.description: The average time taken to replicate data around the cluster. May return null if the cache is not started.

stop-timeout.description: If there are any ongoing transactions when a cache is stopped, Infinispan waits for ongoing remote and local transactions to finish. The amount of time to wait for is defined by the cache stop timeout.

rollbacks.description: The number of transaction rollbacks. May return null if the cache is not started.

locking.description: The locking configuration of the cache.

commits.description: The number of transaction commits. May return null if the cache is not started.

prepares.description: The number of transaction prepares. May return null if the cache is not started.

mode.description: Sets the clustered cache mode, ASYNC for asynchronous operation, or SYNC for synchronous operation.

lifespan.description: Maximum lifespan of a cache entry, after which the entry is expired cluster-wide, in milliseconds. -1 means the entries never expire.

max-idle.description: Maximum idle time a cache entry will be maintained in the cache, in milliseconds. If the idle time is exceeded, the entry will be expired cluster-wide. -1 means the entries never expire.

interval.description: Interval (in milliseconds) between subsequent runs to purge expired entries from memory and any cache stores. If you wish to disable the periodic eviction process altogether, set wakeupInterval to -1.

state-transfer.description: The state transfer configuration for distribution and replicated caches.

STATE_TRANSFER.description: The state transfer configuration for distribution and replicated caches.

enabled.description: If enabled, this will cause the cache to ask neighboring caches for state when it starts up, so the cache starts 'warm', although it will impact startup time.

chunk-size.description: The size, in bytes, in which to batch the transfer of cache entries.

timeout.description: The maximum amount of time (ms) to wait for state from neighboring caches, before throwing an exception and aborting startup.

strategy.description: Sets the cache eviction strategy. Available options are 'UNORDERED', 'FIFO', 'LRU', 'LIRS' and 'NONE' (to disable eviction).

max-entries.description: Maximum number of entries in a cache instance. If selected value is not a power of two the actual value will default to the least power of two larger than selected value. -1 means no limit.

evictions.description: The number of cache eviction operations. May return null if the cache is not started.

locking.description: The locking configuration of the cache.

LOCKING.description: The locking configuration of the cache.

number-of-locks-held.description: The number of locks currently in use by this cache. May return null if the cache is not started.

isolation.description: Sets the cache locking isolation level.

current-concurrency-level.description: The estimated number of concurrently updating threads which this cache can support. May return null if the cache is not started.

acquire-timeout.description: Maximum time to attempt a particular lock acquisition.

number-of-locks-available.description: The number of locks available to this cache. May return null if the cache is not started.

striping.description: If true, a pool of shared locks is maintained for all entries that need to be locked. Otherwise, a lock is created per entry in the cache. Lock striping helps control memory footprint but may reduce concurrency in the system.

concurrency-level.description: Concurrency level for lock containers. Adjust this value according to the number of concurrent threads interacting with Infinispan.

string-keyed-jdbc-store.description: The string keyed cache JDBC store configuration.

STRING_KEYED_JDBC_STORE.description: The string keyed cache JDBC store configuration.

shared.description: This setting should be set to true when multiple cache instances share the same cache store (e.g., multiple nodes in a cluster using a JDBC-based CacheStore pointing to the same, shared database.) Setting this to true avoids multiple cache instances writing the same modification multiple times. If enabled, only the node where the modification originated will write to the cache store. If disabled, each individual cache reacts to a potential remote update by storing the data to the cache store.

cache-loader-loads.description: The number of cache loader node loads. May return null if the cache is not started.

passivation.description: If true, data is only written to the cache store when it is evicted from memory, a phenomenon known as 'passivation'. Next time the data is requested, it will be 'activated' which means that data will be brought back to memory and removed from the persistent store. f false, the cache store contains a copy of the contents in memory, so writes to cache result in cache store writes. This essentially gives you a 'write-through' configuration.

fetch-state.description: If true, fetch persistent state when joining a cluster. If multiple cache stores are chained, only one of them can have this property enabled.

singleton.description: If true, the singleton store cache store is enabled. SingletonStore is a delegating cache store used for situations when only one instance in a cluster should interact with the underlying store.

cache-loader-misses.description: The number of cache loader node misses. May return null if the cache is not started.

string-keyed-table.description: The database table used to store cache entries.

prefix.description: The prefix for the database table name.

batch-size.description: For DB inserts, the batch size determines how many inserts are batched together.

fetch-size.description: For DB queries, the fetch size will be used to set the fetch size on ResultSets.

id-column.description: A database column to hold cache entry ids.

name.description: The name of the database column.

type.description: The type of the database column.

data-column.description: A database column to hold cache entry data.

name.description: The name of the database column.

type.description: The type of the database column.

timestamp-column.description: A database column to hold cache entry timestamps.

name.description: The name of the database column.

type.description: The type of the database column.

preload.description: If true, when the cache starts, data stored in the cache store will be pre-loaded into memory. This is particularly useful when data in the cache store will be needed immediately after startup and you want to avoid cache operations being delayed as a result of loading this data lazily. Can be used to provide a 'warm-cache' on startup, however there is a performance penalty as startup time is affected by this process.

purge.description: If true, purges this cache store when it starts up.

datasource.description: A datasource reference for this datastore.

write-behind.description: Configures a cache store as write-behind instead of write-through.

WRITE_BEHIND.description: Configures a cache store as write-behind instead of write-through.

modification-queue-size.description: Maximum number of entries in the asynchronous queue. When the queue is full, the store becomes write-through until it can accept new entries.

flush-lock-timeout.description: Timeout to acquire the lock which guards the state to be flushed to the cache store periodically.

thread-pool-size.description: Size of the thread pool whose threads are responsible for applying the modifications to the cache store.

shutdown-timeout.description: Timeout in milliseconds to stop the cache store.

This is particularly useful when data in the cache store will be needed immediately after startup and you want to avoid cache operations being delayed as a result of loading this data lazily. Can be used to provide a 'warm-cache' on startup, however there is a performance penalty as startup time is affected by this process.

purge.description: If true, purges this cache store when it starts up.

write-behind.description: Configures a cache store as write-behind instead of write-through.

WRITE_BEHIND.description: Configures a cache store as write-behind instead of write-through.

modification-queue-size.description: Maximum number of entries in the asynchronous queue. When the queue is full, the store becomes write-through until it can accept new entries.

flush-lock-timeout.description: Timeout to acquire the lock which guards the state to be flushed to the cache store periodically.

thread-pool-size.description: Size of the thread pool whose threads are responsible for applying the modifications to the cache store.

shutdown-timeout.description: Timeout in milliseconds to stop the cache store.

property.description: A cache store property with name and value.

*.description: A cache store property with name and value.

value.description: The value of the cache store property.

shared.description: This setting should be set to true when multiple cache instances share the same cache store (e.g., multiple nodes in a cluster using a JDBC-based CacheStore pointing to the same, shared database.) Setting this to true avoids multiple cache instances writing the same modification multiple times. If enabled, only the node where the modification originated will write to the cache store. If disabled, each individual cache reacts to a potential remote update by storing the data to the cache store.

cache-loader-loads.description: The number of cache loader node loads. May return null if the cache is not started.

passivation.description: If true, data is only written to the cache store when it is evicted from memory, a phenomenon known as 'passivation'. Next time the data is requested, it will be 'activated' which means that data will be brought back to memory and removed from the persistent store. f false, the cache store contains a copy of the contents in memory, so writes to cache result in cache store writes. This essentially gives you a 'write-through' configuration.

fetch-state.description: If true, fetch persistent state when joining a cluster. If multiple cache stores are chained, only one of them can have this property enabled.

singleton.description: If true, the singleton store cache store is enabled. SingletonStore is a delegating cache store used for situations when only one instance in a cluster should interact with the underlying store.

preload.description: If true, when the cache starts, data stored in the cache store will be pre-loaded into memory. This is particularly useful when data in the cache store will be needed immediately after startup and you want to avoid cache operations being delayed as a result of loading this data lazily. Can be used to provide a 'warm-cache' on startup, however there is a performance penalty as startup time is affected by this process.

property.description: A cache store property with name and value.

*.description: A cache store property with name and value.

value.description: The value of the cache store property.

invalidation-cache.description: An invalidation cache child of the cache container.

*.description: An invalidation cache

cache-status.description: The status of the cache component. May return null if the cache is not started.

hit-ratio.description: The hit/miss ratio for the cache (hits/hits+misses). May return null if the cache is not started.

indexing.description: If enabled, entries will be indexed when they are added to the cache. Indexes will be updated as entries change or are removed.

passivations.description: The number of cache node passivations (passivating a node from memory to a cache store). May return null if the cache is not started.

remove-misses.description: The number of cache attribute remove misses. May return null if the cache is not started.

misses.description: The number of cache attribute misses. May return null if the cache is not started.

mode.description: Sets the clustered cache mode, ASYNC for asynchronous operation, or SYNC for synchronous operation.

remote-timeout.description: In SYNC mode, the timeout (in ms) used to wait for an acknowledgment when making a remote call, after which the call is aborted and an exception is thrown.

number-of-entries.description: The current number of entries in the cache. May return null if the cache is not started.

time-since-reset.description: Time (in secs) since cache statistics were reset. May return null if the cache is not started.

jndi-name.description: The jndi-name to which to bind this cache instance.

elapsed-time.description: Time (in secs) since cache started. May return null if the cache is not started.

read-write-ratio.description: The read/write ratio of the cache ((hits+misses)/stores). May return null if the cache is not started.

remove-hits.description: The number of cache attribute remove hits. May return null if the cache is not started.

queue-size.description: In ASYNC mode, this attribute can be used to trigger flushing of the queue when it reaches a specific threshold.

async-marshalling.description: If enabled, this will cause marshalling of entries to be performed asynchronously.

queue-flush-interval.description: In ASYNC mode, this attribute controls how often the asynchronous thread used to flush the replication queue runs. This should be a positive integer which represents thread wakeup time in milliseconds.

replication-count.description: The number of times data was replicated around the cluster. May return null if the cache is not started.

module.description: The module whose class loader should be used when building this cache's configuration.

average-read-time.description: Average time (in ms) for cache reads. Includes hits and misses. May return null if the cache is not started.

success-ratio.description: The data replication success ratio (successes/successes+failures). May return null if the cache is not started.

invalidations.description: The number of cache invalidations. May return null if the cache is not started.

replication-failures.description: The number of data replication failures. May return null if the cache is not started.

statistics-enabled.description: If enabled, statistics will be collected for this cache

hits.description: The number of cache attribute hits. May return null if the cache is not started.

batching.description: If enabled, the invocation batching API will be made available for this cache.

start.description: The cache start mode, which can be EAGER (immediate start) or LAZY (on-demand start).

average-write-time.description: Average time (in ms) for cache writes. May return null if the cache is not started.

stores.description: The number of cache attribute put operations. May return null if the cache is not started.

average-replication-time.description: The average time taken to replicate data around the cluster. May return null if the cache is not started.

stop-timeout.description: If there are any ongoing transactions when a cache is stopped, Infinispan waits for ongoing remote and local transactions to finish. The amount of time to wait for is defined by the cache stop timeout.

rollbacks.description: The number of transaction rollbacks. May return null if the cache is not started.

locking.description: The locking configuration of the cache.

commits.description: The number of transaction commits. May return null if the cache is not started.

prepares.description: The number of transaction prepares. May return null if the cache is not started.

mode.description: Sets the clustered cache mode, ASYNC for asynchronous operation, or SYNC for synchronous operation.

lifespan.description: Maximum lifespan of a cache entry, after which the entry is expired cluster-wide, in milliseconds. -1 means the entries never expire.

max-idle.description: Maximum idle time a cache entry will be maintained in the cache, in milliseconds. If the idle time is exceeded, the entry will be expired cluster-wide. -1 means the entries never expire.

interval.description: Interval (in milliseconds) between subsequent runs to purge expired entries from memory and any cache stores. If you wish to disable the periodic eviction process altogether, set wakeupInterval to -1.

strategy.description: Sets the cache eviction strategy. Available options are 'UNORDERED', 'FIFO', 'LRU', 'LIRS' and 'NONE' (to disable eviction).

max-entries.description: Maximum number of entries in a cache instance. If selected value is not a power of two the actual value will default to the least power of two larger than selected value. -1 means no limit.

evictions.description: The number of cache eviction operations. May return null if the cache is not started.

locking.description: The locking configuration of the cache.

LOCKING.description: The locking configuration of the cache.

number-of-locks-held.description: The number of locks currently in use by this cache. May return null if the cache is not started.

isolation.description: Sets the cache locking isolation level.

current-concurrency-level.description: The estimated number of concurrently updating threads which this cache can support. May return null if the cache is not started.

acquire-timeout.description: Maximum time to attempt a particular lock acquisition.

number-of-locks-available.description: The number of locks available to this cache. May return null if the cache is not started.

striping.description: If true, a pool of shared locks is maintained for all entries that need to be locked. Otherwise, a lock is created per entry in the cache. Lock striping helps control memory footprint but may reduce concurrency in the system.

concurrency-level.description: Concurrency level for lock containers. Adjust this value according to the number of concurrent threads interacting with Infinispan.

remote-timeout.description: In SYNC mode, the timeout (in ms) used to wait for an acknowledgment when making a remote call, after which the call is aborted and an exception is thrown.

number-of-entries.description: The current number of entries in the cache. May return null if the cache is not started.

time-since-reset.description: Time (in secs) since cache statistics were reset. May return null if the cache is not started.

jndi-name.description: The jndi-name to which to bind this cache instance.

elapsed-time.description: Time (in secs) since cache started. May return null if the cache is not started.

read-write-ratio.description: The read/write ratio of the cache ((hits+misses)/stores). May return null if the cache is not started.

remove-hits.description: The number of cache attribute remove hits. May return null if the cache is not started.

queue-size.description: In ASYNC mode, this attribute can be used to trigger flushing of the queue when it reaches a specific threshold.

async-marshalling.description: If enabled, this will cause marshalling of entries to be performed asynchronously.

queue-flush-interval.description: In ASYNC mode, this attribute controls how often the asynchronous thread used to flush the replication queue runs. This should be a positive integer which represents thread wakeup time in milliseconds.

replication-count.description: The number of times data was replicated around the cluster. May return null if the cache is not started.

module.description: The module whose class loader should be used when building this cache's configuration.

average-read-time.description: Average time (in ms) for cache reads. Includes hits and misses. May return null if the cache is not started.

success-ratio.description: The data replication success ratio (successes/successes+failures). May return null if the cache is not started.

invalidations.description: The number of cache invalidations. May return null if the cache is not started.

replication-failures.description: The number of data replication failures. May return null if the cache is not started.

statistics-enabled.description: If enabled, statistics will be collected for this cache

hits.description: The number of cache attribute hits. May return null if the cache is not started.

batching.description: If enabled, the invocation batching API will be made available for this cache.

start.description: The cache start mode, which can be EAGER (immediate start) or LAZY (on-demand start).

average-write-time.description: Average time (in ms) for cache writes. May return null if the cache is not started.

l1-lifespan.description: Maximum lifespan of an entry placed in the L1 cache. This element configures the L1 cache behavior in 'distributed' caches instances. In any other cache modes, this element is ignored.

stores.description: The number of cache attribute put operations. May return null if the cache is not started.

average-replication-time.description: The average time taken to replicate data around the cluster. May return null if the cache is not started.

owners.description: Number of cluster-wide replicas for each cache entry.

stop-timeout.description: If there are any ongoing transactions when a cache is stopped, Infinispan waits for ongoing remote and local transactions to finish. The amount of time to wait for is defined by the cache stop timeout.

rollbacks.description: The number of transaction rollbacks. May return null if the cache is not started.

locking.description: The locking configuration of the cache.

commits.description: The number of transaction commits. May return null if the cache is not started.

prepares.description: The number of transaction prepares. May return null if the cache is not started.

mode.description: Sets the clustered cache mode, ASYNC for asynchronous operation, or SYNC for synchronous operation.

lifespan.description: Maximum lifespan of a cache entry, after which the entry is expired cluster-wide, in milliseconds. -1 means the entries never expire.

max-idle.description: Maximum idle time a cache entry will be maintained in the cache, in milliseconds. If the idle time is exceeded, the entry will be expired cluster-wide. -1 means the entries never expire.

interval.description: Interval (in milliseconds) between subsequent runs to purge expired entries from memory and any cache stores. If you wish to disable the periodic eviction process altogether, set wakeupInterval to -1.

state-transfer.description: The state transfer configuration for distribution and replicated caches.

STATE_TRANSFER.description: The state transfer configuration for distribution and replicated caches.

enabled.description: If enabled, this will cause the cache to ask neighboring caches for state when it starts up, so the cache starts 'warm', although it will impact startup time.

chunk-size.description: The size, in bytes, in which to batch the transfer of cache entries.

timeout.description: The maximum amount of time (ms) to wait for state from neighboring caches, before throwing an exception and aborting startup.

strategy.description: Sets the cache eviction strategy. Available options are 'UNORDERED', 'FIFO', 'LRU', 'LIRS' and 'NONE' (to disable eviction).

max-entries.description: Maximum number of entries in a cache instance. If selected value is not a power of two the actual value will default to the least power of two larger than selected value. -1 means no limit.

evictions.description: The number of cache eviction operations. May return null if the cache is not started.

locking.description: The locking configuration of the cache.

LOCKING.description: The locking configuration of the cache.

number-of-locks-held.description: The number of locks currently in use by this cache. May return null if the cache is not started.

isolation.description: Sets the cache locking isolation level.

current-concurrency-level.description: The estimated number of concurrently updating threads which this cache can support. May return null if the cache is not started.

acquire-timeout.description: Maximum time to attempt a particular lock acquisition.

number-of-locks-available.description: The number of locks available to this cache. May return null if the cache is not started.

striping.description: If true, a pool of shared locks is maintained for all entries that need to be locked. Otherwise, a lock is created per entry in the cache. Lock striping helps control memory footprint but may reduce concurrency in the system.

concurrency-level.description: Concurrency level for lock containers. Adjust this value according to the number of concurrent threads interacting with Infinispan.

string-keyed-jdbc-store.description: The string keyed cache JDBC store configuration.

STRING_KEYED_JDBC_STORE.description: The string keyed cache JDBC store configuration.

shared.description: This setting should be set to true when multiple cache instances share the same cache store (e.g., multiple nodes in a cluster using a JDBC-based CacheStore pointing to the same, shared database.) Setting this to true avoids multiple cache instances writing the same modification multiple times. If enabled, only the node where the modification originated will write to the cache store. If disabled, each individual cache reacts to a potential remote update by storing the data to the cache store.

cache-loader-loads.description: The number of cache loader node loads. May return null if the cache is not started.

passivation.description: If true, data is only written to the cache store when it is evicted from memory, a phenomenon known as 'passivation'. Next time the data is requested, it will be 'activated' which means that data will be brought back to memory and removed from the persistent store. f false, the cache store contains a copy of the contents in memory, so writes to cache result in cache store writes. This essentially gives you a 'write-through' configuration.

fetch-state.description: If true, fetch persistent state when joining a cluster. If multiple cache stores are chained, only one of them can have this property enabled.

singleton.description: If true, the singleton store cache store is enabled. SingletonStore is a delegating cache store used for situations when only one instance in a cluster should interact with the underlying store.

cache-loader-misses.description: The number of cache loader node misses. May return null if the cache is not started.

string-keyed-table.description: The database table used to store cache entries.

prefix.description: The prefix for the database table name.

batch-size.description: For DB inserts, the batch size determines how many inserts are batched together.

fetch-size.description: For DB queries, the fetch size will be used to set the fetch size on ResultSets.

id-column.description: A database column to hold cache entry ids.

name.description: The name of the database column.

type.description: The type of the database column.

data-column.description: A database column to hold cache entry data.

name.description: The name of the database column.

type.description: The type of the database column.

timestamp-column.description: A database column to hold cache entry timestamps.

name.description: The name of the database column.

type.description: The type of the database column.

preload.description: If true, when the cache starts, data stored in the cache store will be pre-loaded into memory. This is particularly useful when data in the cache store will be needed immediately after startup and you want to avoid cache operations being delayed as a result of loading this data lazily. Can be used to provide a 'warm-cache' on startup, however there is a performance penalty as startup time is affected by this process.

purge.description: If true, purges this cache store when it starts up.

datasource.description: A datasource reference for this datastore.

write-behind.description: Configures a cache store as write-behind instead of write-through.

WRITE_BEHIND.description: Configures a cache store as write-behind instead of write-through.

modification-queue-size.description: Maximum number of entries in the asynchronous queue. When the queue is full, the store becomes write-through until it can accept new entries.

flush-lock-timeout.description: Timeout to acquire the lock which guards the state to be flushed to the cache store periodically.

thread-pool-size.description: Size of the thread pool whose threads are responsible for applying the modifications to the cache store.

shutdown-timeout.description: Timeout in milliseconds to stop the cache store.

cache-loader-loads.description: The number of cache loader node loads. May return null if the cache is not started.

passivation.description: If true, data is only written to the cache store when it is evicted from memory, a phenomenon known as 'passivation'. Next time the data is requested, it will be 'activated' which means that data will be brought back to memory and removed from the persistent store. f false, the cache store contains a copy of the contents in memory, so writes to cache result in cache store writes. This essentially gives you a 'write-through' configuration.

fetch-state.description: If true, fetch persistent state when joining a cluster. If multiple cache stores are chained, only one of them can have this property enabled.

singleton.description: If true, the singleton store cache store is enabled. SingletonStore is a delegating cache store used for situations when only one instance in a cluster should interact with the underlying store.

cache-loader-misses.description: The number of cache loader node misses. May return null if the cache is not started.

default-security-domain.description: The default security domain that will be used for EJBs if the bean doesn't explicitly specify one

default-entity-bean-optimistic-locking.description: If set to true entity beans will use optimistic locking by default

in-vm-remote-interface-invocation-pass-b.description: If set to false, the parameters to invocations on remote interface of an EJB, will be passed by reference. Else, the parameters will be passed by value.

default-missing-method-permissions-deny-.description: If this is set to true then methods on an EJB with a security domain specified or with other methods with security metadata will have an implicit @DenyAll unless other security metadata is present

default-clustered-sfsb-cache.description: Name of the default stateful bean cache, which will be applicable to all clustered stateful EJBs, unless overridden at the deployment or bean level

default-entity-bean-instance-pool.description: Name of the default entity bean instance pool, which will be applicable to all entity beans, unless overridden at the deployment or bean level

default-distinct-name.description: The default distinct name that is applied to every EJB deployed on this server

default-singleton-bean-access-timeout.description: The default access timeout for singleton beans

default-sfsb-cache.description: Name of the default stateful bean cache, which will be applicable to all stateful EJBs, unless overridden at the deployment or bean level

default-resource-adapter-name.description: Name of the default resource adapter name that will be used by MDBs, unless overridden at the deployment or bean level

enable-statistics.description: If set to true, enable the collection of invocation statistics.

default-stateful-bean-access-timeout.description: The default access timeout for stateful beans

default-slsb-instance-pool.description: Name of the default stateless bean instance pool, which will be applicable to all stateless EJBs, unless overridden at the deployment or bean level

thread-pool-name.description: The name of the thread pool which handles asynchronous invocations

enable-by-default.description: If this is true EJB's will be exposed over IIOP by default, otherwise it needs to be explicitly enabled in the deployment descriptor

use-qualified-name.description: If true EJB names will be bound into the naming service with the application and module name prepended to the name (e.g. myapp/mymodule/MyEjb)

thread-pool-name.description: The name of the thread pool that handles remote invocations

connector-ref.description: The name of the connector on which the EJB3 remoting channel is registered

channel-creation-options.description: The options that will be used during the EJB remote channel creation
